ygData.subject: Re: HybrID: A Hybridization of Indirect and Direct Encodings for Evolutionary Computation
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, I respond to your points below. ... But is the quadruped really representative of real-world problems that nature solved?  I don t think the quadruped

From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
Subject: Re: HybrID: A Hybridization of Indirect and Direct Encodings for Evolutionary Computation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=GaVoUQd6gJwaGnUpDwH9rSx3inl7WErpl8NdKx8p6y7ohqW7M1MP
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Jeff, I respond to your points below.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Cl=
une <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello Ken-
> 
> Thanks for sharing your thought=
s on this issue. I agree with you that one of
> the interesting things the =
HybrID paper does is get us thinking about what
> we want out of encodings.=

> 
> Here are a few reactions to your comments:
> 
> Initially, I fully ac=
knowledge (and even trumpet the fact) that HyperNEAT
> can produce many typ=
es of variations on themes and irregularities. If I have
> given a differen=
t impression somewhere, that was unintentional. You are
> right that HyperN=
EAT just seems to have difficulties making *certain types*
> of exceptions,=
 however I still think the exceptions it has trouble making
> are ones that=
 we want it to be able to make.
> 
> You have convinced me (in previous con=
versations) that we do not need (nor
> want) our encodings to have the abil=
ity to match an arbitrary target.
> However, the experimental results from =
the quadruped domain in the HybrID
> paper show that the ability to make ex=
ceptions boosts fitness, even in a
> complicated, real-world problem. That =
is the type of problems that nature
> (with DNA) did solve, so my guess is =
that we still have some work to do when
> it comes to creating encodings th=
at simultaneously generate regularities and
> exceptions. I am guessing tha=
t the solutions HybrID produced that HyperNEAT
> alone did not produce were=
 not the only possible solution (such as might be
> described as a pre-set =
target), but instead were instances of a class of
> solutions that were les=
s-regular than the HyperNEAT-only gaits. To me that
> indicates that HyperN=
EAT is not only constrained from discovering arbitrary,
> ad-hoc, academic =
irregularities, but instead has difficulty producing some
> irregularities =
which help on normal, everyday, complex problems.  My
> instincts tell me t=
hat to get to true AI we are going to need to make these
> types of excepti=
ons.
> 

But is the quadruped really representative of "real-world" problem=
s that nature solved?  I don't think the quadruped solution is anything lik=
e nature's solutions to quadruped walking.  The HybrID quadruped was allowe=
d to *further* evolve to adjust to joint faults, whereas real-life quadrupe=
ds would simply adapt during their lifetime, which is a major difference.  =
In fact, walking solutions in the real world are adaptive and malleable, no=
t canned circuits that only produce a single gait.  If a dog hurts its knee=
, it changes how it walks.  The HyrbrID quadruped can't do that.  Even an i=
nsect that loses a leg can adjust and keep walking.  

Thus my guess is tha=
t the underlying encoding in nature is regular after all, and the irregular=
ity that may ultimately arise within the brain is because of changes that a=
re guided by adaptive rules.  But what the DNA codes for are those *rules*,=
 not the changes that the rules produce.  Thus the rules themselves can cer=
tainly be distributed in a regular pattern.  If an irregular fault then ari=
ses, the rules for how that local area should change will cause changes for=
 that area.  In fact, the rules must be distributed in a mostly regular man=
ner:  How could it be that you should somehow adapt differently to a right =
knee fault than to a left one?  The underlying concept of adaptation is sym=
metric.

So I still do not see evidence that CPPNs, nor nature for that mat=
ter, should be expected to encode for ad hoc irregularities such as a creat=
ure that is born with a single gait attuned to an asymmetric body with a ba=
d knee.  That is, creatures derive their gaits from their bodies, not vice-=
versa.  They sense their limbs once they are alive and adapt the way they m=
ove to the limbs with which they find themselves.  Hopefully those limbs ar=
e intact, but if not, or if they become disabled, they adapt.


> You raise=
 the issue that getting better at making exceptions also makes us
> worse a=
t creating regularities.  But is it necessarily the case that there
> is a =
non-zero-sum tradeoff in encoding regularities and exceptions? I can
> conc=
eive of a different activation function set for HyperNEAT in which we
> add=
 functions that help it make exceptions in small areas of the geometric
> s=
pace. This enlarged function set would still have all of the same power to
=
> generate regularities as the standard set, but it would also have the
> a=
dditional ability to create exceptions. Especially if this activation
> fun=
ction was rarely used (either because it mutated in at a lower rate, or
> b=
ecause evolution chose to use it sparingly), the overall type of solutions
=
> might not be biased back into the chaos of direct encodings. Clearly ther=
e
> is some bias back in that direction, but I am wondering (out loud) if i=
t
> really has to be non-zero-some in the sense that whatever you gain in
>=
 exception-making you lose in regularity-making. Might an elegant solution
=
> get us a lot of one without too much loss of the other?
> 

It certainly =
could be possible that some new set of activation functions or augmentation=
s of CPPNs could be better at producing the kinds of regularities and excep=
tions that are most effective for building brains.  But I do think that it =
is incorrect to frame this issue as a problem with capturing exceptions.  I=
 mean, I guess I don't accept the premise of the question of whether it is =
a zero-sum game.  That question assumes that somehow we need more exception=
s, but I do not see evidence for that.  I can think of innumerable possible=
 "exceptions" for animal body plans, but nature would be able to evolve vir=
tually none of them, even with proper selection pressure.  How about finger=
s coming out of one ear, or a tongue on the bottom of one foot?  Or maybe o=
ne half side of the body entirely covered in hair but the other bald?  Or m=
aybe we could breed babies to be born with a nice smiley-face tattoo on one=
 cheek?  

These are ridiculous, but I do not see any clear a priori distin=
ction that you have articulated between what is ridiculous and what isn't. =
 You seem to have the intuition that what HybrID produces is exactly in the=
 class of "not ridiculous" exceptions, but in my view just because somethin=
g worked does not mean it has any relation to nature at all.  Still, ok, it=
 doesn't have to be like nature, but the question is whether it somehow set=
s up a new ideal vision for indirect encodings.  And I don't see that becau=
se I think the quadruped born with the broken joint is no less arbitrary th=
an a baby with a smiley-face tattoo.   

So you might wonder what irregular=
ities I would think are not arbitrary.  The things that are not arbitrary a=
re those irregular motifs that I intuitively observe in nature such as impe=
rfect symmetry (e.g. the heart on one side or right-handedness) and repetit=
ion with variation (e.g. receptive field patterns in the brain or fingers o=
n the hand).  

It's hard for me to think of major exceptions.  Maybe the l=
obster's claw?  But of course in all the immensity of nature there will be =
here and there a bizarre occurrence, but those do not make a rule.  (And an=
yway, to my intuition the lobster's claw is more a kind of imperfect symmet=
ry than an arbitrary exception.)

Admittedly, a lot of what I'm going on he=
re is intuition rather than logic. 

> In fact, isn't HybrID an example of =
this? Mutation-selection balance aside,
> FT-NEAT should only make a change=
 to a pattern HyperNEAT produced if the
> change helps fitness. I realize H=
ybrID is not the long-term solution (partly
> because of the scaling issues=
 you mentioned), but isn't it at least an
> example of how an algorithm can=
 make advances on the exception-making front
> without losing much, if anyt=
hing, on the producing-regularity front?
> 

That's a really good question/=
argument, and it is worth thinking about.  But ultimately I would not draw =
that conclusion from HybrID.  Rather, I would say that it simply works in p=
ractice on lower-dimensional structures, and I would not draw any more gene=
ral lesson from it on the potential for representing more exceptions.  My g=
uess is that if such a power were available at much higher dimensionalities=
, it would add a kind of noise on top of whatever regularity might be disco=
vered, thereby handicapping the ability to discover regularity.  That is, m=
y guess is that the ability to make completely arbitrary regular exceptions=
 probably would not scale well.  Since scaling to massive sizes is part of =
what interests me, I would need more evidence to convince me that there is =
a need for such exception-making at large scales.

Let me conclude by empha=
sizing that I am *not* suggesting that CPPNs in their present form are the =
best encoding we will ever get.  There may indeed be better ones (and it's =
worth investigating), but what I think would make them better is not trying=
 to get "more exceptions" but rather trying to figure out what kinds of exc=
eptions there should be and what kinds of regularities there should be and =
where they would all fit into the big picture.  That is, to me it is more a=
 question of kind than a question of degree.  And unfortunately, arguments =
about kind are much more specific and hair-splitting than general arguments=
 about degree.

ken 


> Thanks again for your interesting comments.
> 
> 
=
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State Universit=
y
> 
> jclune@...
> 
> 
> 
> 
> > From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> > =
Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Date: Sun, 26 J=
ul 2009 23:29:15 -0000
> > To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com=
>
> > Subject: [neat] Re: HybrID: A Hybridization of Indirect and Direct En=
codings
> > for Evolutionary Computation
> > 
> > Jeff knows some of my tho=
ughts on the issue of regularity vs. irregularity in
> > neuroevolution and=
 also that I recognize the nice results with HybrID, so this
> > post is ju=
st my attempt to put out some thoughts on this important issue,
> > rather =
than a challenge to the HybrID concept.  Basically, HybrID creates a
> > go=
od opportunity to discuss these issues.
> > 
> > Taking a long term view, w=
hat I would like to question is the idea that there
> > is a problem with a=
 method that has "trouble" discovering arbitrary
> > irregularities.  It im=
portant to note that HyperNEAT has no trouble
> > representing "irregularit=
y" in the general sense.  In my 2007 paper on CPPNs
> > (http://eplex.cs.uc=
f.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html), I included explicit
> > examples of ir=
regularities and how easy they are to represent.  For example,
> > see the =
"Warped Symmetry" panel in figure 9 on page 24.  So I think the issue
> > i=
s definitively *not* that HyperNEAT (or more specifically, CPPNs with a
> >=
 certain set of activation functions) has trouble representing or discoveri=
ng
> > irregularity, but that it has trouble discovering *particular* irreg=
ularities.
> > 
> > Yet such trouble may actually be a good thing.  If it w=
ere too easy to
> > represent any arbitrary irregularity, then you would ha=
ve an encoding that is
> > poor at discovering regularities.  So this argum=
ent could go in circles.  But
> > it's important to recognize that we are l=
ooking at a trade-off.  Nature faces
> > the same trade-off.  It is difficu=
lt to say for sure whether DNA is biased
> > towards regularity or irregula=
rity, but I would guess looking at biological
> > organisms that regularity=
 reigns, and that irregularities are of certain
> > *types*, that is, you w=
ould be hard pressed to "breed" a human with a hand
> > protruding from his=
 or her right knee, no matter how many generations were
> > available.  Yet=
 we see things like the heart on one side, right-handedness,
> > etc.  But =
those do not mean that the encoding can simply bend to the arbitrary
> > wh=
ims of a random target.
> > 
> > So I think what you need if you want to ev=
olve a really interesting artifact
> > is not an encoding that is entirely =
flexible with respect to irregularity.  If
> > a particular encoding would =
often fail to meet ad hoc irregular targets, that
> > is probably a sign of=
 its long term potential, rather something we'd want to
> > fix.  If we did=
 "fix" it, we'd be heading back towards the chaos and entropy
> > of direct=
 encoding.
> > 
> > Therefore, we should be careful about whether we consid=
er difficulty achieving
> > specific irregularities a problem to solve or a=
n asset in the long run.
> > Certainly there should an ability to create "r=
epetition with variation," but
> > CPPNs (as well as nature) exhibit that c=
onsistently.  So it's important to be
> > careful what we consider to be a =
pathology versus an asset.
> > 
> > That said, HybrID is a good practical i=
dea.  It is clear that in some problems
> > it is just what is needed to pe=
rfect solutions with particular irregular
> > needs.  Of course, when the n=
etworks become really big, e.g. with millions of
> > connections, HybrID mi=
ght begin to lose some of its ability to cope with the
> > very high dimens=
ionality, even if it is just tweaking on top of preexisting
> > regularitie=
s encoded by the CPPN.  Nevertheless, at lower dimensionalities, as
> > Jef=
f's paper shows, it can really help.
> > 
> > In any case, my main point is=
 that the issue of what we actually *want* in an
> > encoding with respect =
to regularity and irregularity is quite subtle and
> > deserves considered =
contemplation.  The CPPN with the usual set of activation
> > functions may=
 not ultimately be the very best representation to bias towards
> > what we=
 want, but if there is something better, it would not be better by
> > virt=
ue of simply being able to capture irregularities more easily.  Rather,
> >=
 any advantage would be gained through a much more subtle argument, which
>=
 > likely refers to both regularities and irregularities of certain types, =
and
> > why they are appropriate for the kinds of neural structures we hope=
 to evolve.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <=
jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Hello all-
> >> 
> >> Recently I have shown that=
 HyperNEAT has trouble making exceptions to the
> >> rules it discovers (Cl=
une et al. PPSN 2008). I would like to introduce a new
> >> paper that will=
 be at ECAL 2009 which shows one way to remedy this problem:
> >> combining=
 a generative encoding (HyperNEAT in this case) with a direct
> >> encoding=
 (FT-NEAT in this case).
> >> 
> >> The resulting algorithm, which we call =
HybrID (Hybridization of Indirect and
> >> Direct Encodings), combines the =
best of both encodings, and outperformed
> >> HyperNEAT on all of the probl=
ems we tested it on, sometimes by as much as
> >> 40%. 
> >> 
> >> I'd be r=
eally interested to hear what the people on this list think of the
> >> wor=
k. For example, I'll bet there are interesting ways to remedy the problem
>=
 >> of making exceptions within HyperNEAT, and it would be interesting for =
us as
> >> a community to explore them. But in the interim, if any of you a=
re deploying
> >> HyperNEAT on some task and want a possible performance bo=
ost, HybrID is easy
> >> to implement and may lead to a significant improve=
ment.
> >> 
> >> Here is a link to the paper:
> >> https://www.msu.edu/~jcl=
une/webfiles/publications/Clune-HybrID-ECAL-2009.pdf
> >> 
> >> Here is the=
 abstract from the paper:
> >> 
> >> Evolutionary algorithms typically use =
direct encodings, where each element
> >> of the phenotype is specified ind=
ependently in the genotype. Because direct
> >> encodings have difficulty e=
volving modular and symmetric phenotypes, some
> >> researchers use indirec=
t encodings, wherein one genomic element can
> >> influence multiple parts =
of a phenotype. We have previously shown that
> >> HyperNEAT, an indirect e=
ncoding, outperforms FT-NEAT, a direct-encoding
> >> control, on many probl=
ems, especially as the regularity of the problem
> >> increases. However, H=
yperNEAT is no panacea; it had difficulty accounting
> >> for irregularitie=
s in problems. In this paper, we propose a new algorithm, a
> >> Hybridized=
 Indirect and Direct encoding (HybrID), which discovers the
> >> regularity=
 of a problem with an indirect encoding and accounts for
> >> irregularitie=
s via a direct encoding. In three different problem domains,
> >> HybrID ou=
tperforms HyperNEAT in most situations, with performance
> >> improvements =
as large as 40%. Our work suggests that hybridizing indirect
> >> and direc=
t encodings can be an effective way to improve the performance of
> >> evol=
utionary algorithms.
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
>=
 >> 
> >> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> >>

e@
